title: AB 2854
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature submits an act to the electors, stating that the theft of firearms poses unique dangers to public safety. The value of handguns is often less than $950, but the threat they pose goes beyond monetary value. Restoring penalties for stolen firearms is deemed necessary. The intent is not to undermine voters' decisions. The Legislature proposes amending Penal Code Section 490.2 to restore penalties for firearm theft and receipt of stolen firearms, recognizing the unique dangers they pose to public safety. This amendment does not undermine voters' decision to decrease penalties for low-level theft and receiving stolen property. Section 490.2 of the Penal Code is amended to state that theft of property under $950 is considered petty theft and punishable as a misdemeanor, with exceptions for prior convictions. This does not apply to theft charges that can be classified as infractions under other laws. The theft of a firearm is considered grand theft and is punishable under Section 489 of the Penal Code. Section 496 is amended to address this issue. Section 496 of the Penal Code addresses the buying, receiving, or concealing of stolen property, with punishment ranging from misdemeanor to imprisonment based on the value of the property and prior convictions. A principal involved in the theft of property can be convicted under this section, but cannot be convicted of both this offense and the theft of the same property. Every swap meet vendor, person dealing in merchandise, or their representatives who buy stolen property over $950 without making reasonable inquiries can be imprisoned for up to one year. Every swap meet vendor, person dealing in merchandise, or their representatives who buy stolen property under $950 without making reasonable inquiries can be guilty of a misdemeanor. Injured parties can seek three times the actual damages, costs of suit, and attorney's fees. Buying or receiving a stolen firearm, or aiding in concealing or selling one, is punishable by up to one year in county jail or imprisonment under Section 1170. SEC. 4 of the act calls for a special election on June 7 or November 8, 2016, to approve Sections 2 and 3. The election will be consolidated with the statewide primary or general election. The Secretary of State will submit the sections for voter approval. The act calls for a special election on June 7 or November 8, 2016, to approve Sections 2 and 3, which will be consolidated with the statewide primary or general election. This act triggers an election within the meaning of Article IV of the Constitution and will take immediate effect.
